@anilkpandey Hey, since you worked on this PR i want to ask about special case, since we are moving forward with supporting syncd multiple switch instances in the same process, then for example there can be possibility that we do a flush with no attributes, just for a single switch, then we want all fdb entries to be removed from that single switch, this is the case when port=0 and bv_id = 0, but your script (the one in swss-common fdb_flush.lua) will remove all the fdb entries from possible all switches. 
To make this work, an extra param needs to be pushed and checked which is switchId, and cehcking each fdb_entry.switch_id in each entry, before actually making remove.
This switchId must be passed to the lua script and inside checked if fdb entry to be removed comes from that particular switch.
Ideally this swtich Id would need to be checked in other cases too (for example when bv_id is specified and non zero). Since we won't cross pass objects between switches (for example case when passing one bv_id from one switch to another is forbidden) to be extra sure, always switch Id should be checked.
Can you make an update to your script and submit PR ?
Yes, I will create a PR for this change.

Removed from 201811 branch until further validation is done.
the new file name (TimeWatchdog.{h, cpp}) is not consistent with existing file names?

Yes, it not follow current convention, but i took this opportunity to move to a different scheme:
- one class per file
- files names as classes names with Capital letters
- files with classes not prefixed as syncd_*.cpp

i will be doing this refactoring as new changes will be added to syncd/sairedis
this will make more sense in long run and it should keep the project more clean
especially if we plan to support multiple asics in the future, then everything related to single unit switch will be encloses to 1 class representing this unit
why arm is not accepting standard prefixes ? this actually makes code much more messy :/

@kcudnik: The "PRI..." constants get defined differently depending on the architecture you're compiling for, thus making the code more portable. Some archs define a 64-bit int as a `long`, some as a `long long`. Withe this change, we never have to worry about the underlying type.
yea grepped via headers, more portable less readability  XD
Yes, unfortunately we sacrifice readability for portability.

There might still be issue here:
<1> at intforch,  rif flex counter is removed first, then rif:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/blob/master/orchagent/intfsorch.cpp#L563
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/blob/master/orchagent/intfsorch.cpp#L565

but rif operation goes through asicDB channel,  flex counter op uses flexcounterDB,  no receiving order at syncd is guaranteed.

<2> rif vid/rid mapping is removed in syncd with rif delete request,  flex counter removal to be handled if the operation request comes later from flexcounterDB channel.

<3> flexCounterThread as a separate thread may keep collecting counter data for that RIF though it has been deleted.

Did I miss anything here?

i think it will be no collecting counters, since if rif ws removed, queued counters are also cleared,  look here:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/pull/464/files#diff-91b3e380b7f6f4a0a048ca8296a12e0dR2908
i dont know exact internals of collecting counters but this seems ok to me

I see.  Having some stale counters in the counterIdsMap temporarily probably is not fatal with this change, but just results in some error log or stale VID counters inside counterDB (due to the asynchronous processing in flexCounterThread).
not following, what stale counters? they will be removed if vid is not found
Need reference pointer advancement to include https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/commit/dcab09f2881a0b45a2c03c091e641ff66dfada8c, which has the sai_deserialize_buffer_pool_stat prototype

can you resolve the conflict? 

also please have a more description on what changes you add and why.

probably because of parallelism this will not pass unittests, since mlnx.pl and brcm.pl are not designed to work in parallel, they need to be executed separately, since each of those instances uses vssyncd process to perform tests, and when executed in parallel, it will conflict
how can we solve this issue?

not easy, since single test requires a vssyncd to be present as a process, a clean redis db and so on,
we can run each test in separate docker XD, then it should work

is parallelism required for unittests here ? is it getting too slow to execute? or this is just pure cosmetic change to bump debian tool version?, if it's cosmetic change, then parallel run probably can be disabled by some switch

why order here matters? for me seems like non-rpc binaries should be built first, and then rpc

This way the non-RPC binaries will be available after the build, making it possible to use them and to do incremental build for non-RPC if needed, which I think is a more common case than for RPC binaries.

Hi Kamil
saiUpdateSupportedQueueCounters
saiUpdateSupportedPriorityGroupCounters

will probe the get_stat and clear_stat function call capability, and remove the stats that are not supported on certain platforms. This ensures that it is less likely the function call will return error during the actual polling phase.


https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/pull/427#issuecomment-467345516

@kcudnik I agree with you that changes related to sai_stat_id_t seem odd, but they are necessary because sairedis compilation is constrained by SAI heders definition. I would suggest revisiting this uniform declaration of stat functions using sai_stat_id_t because it breaks a lot of code.

As all comments were related to code that is currently removed i see no reason why not to approve and merge.
